newsitem.title: GERMANY: Porsche may make car in Finland - report.
newsitem.headline: Porsche may make car in Finland - report.

text.p: German sportscar maker Dr.Ing.h.c.F Porsche AG is aiming to build its Boxster model in Finland in an effort to slash an order backlog, a German magazine reported on Thursday.

According to the weekly Wirtschaftswoche, Porsche is in talks with Finnish engineering group Valmet Oy to produce at least 5,000 of the two-seat cabriolets to break a production bottleneck at its main plant near Stuttgart.
Porsche and Valmet refused to comment on the report. "Our policy is not to give any kind of comment on this type of thing," a Valmet spokeswoman told Reuters.
A Porsche spokesman said, meanwhile, that the company's board had not yet decided how to deal with strong demand for the Boxster.
Valmet's automotive unit is currently manufacturing Saab's 900 cabriolet model, Opel's Calibra and Russian Euro-Samara cars at its Uusikaupunki plant in south-western Finland.
The Boxster model, which hit the market late last year, has won praise from the motoring press and demand is well in excess of what Porsche had expected.
The Porsche plant in Stuttgart has a capacity of around 30,000 cars, about half of which are expected to be Boxsters and the other half the 911 model.
The German car maker has little scope to cut production of the more-expensive 911 after sales boomed last year.
The Boxster sells in Germany for around 75,000 marks.
Porsche chairman Wendelin Wiedeking has vowed to cut waiting times for the Boxster which have stretched out to 12 months, saying a year is to long to wait for a car.
